Mass nouns, Count nouns and Non-count nouns
Henry Laycock
January 2006
 

Linguists often distinguish count and non-count nouns (count+ and count- nouns; CNs and NCNs, for short). The distinction, though hardly simple, is both exhaustive and natural. In philosophical writings, by contrast, it is more usual to posit a dichotomy of count nouns and mass nouns Â— a dichotomy which is very commonly (and however vaguely) supposed to be of metaphysical or ontological significance. Here I defend the 'standpoint of the linguist', whilst not denying that there are philosophically significant contrasts between count nouns and some sub-sets of non-coun nouns.
